case_name: Goenka and N. Gupta v. the respondent

facts.text: This is Criminal Appeal No. 7 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 7 of 1957. Appeal from the judgment and order dated July 12, 1956, of the Calcutta High Court in Criminal Revision No. 270 of 1956.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated July 12, 1956 of Calcutta High Court in Criminal Revision No. 270 of 1956.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on April 18, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. April 18. The Judgment of Sinha C. J., S. K. Das, K. Das Gupta and N. Rajagopala Ayyangar JJ. was delivered by Das Gupta J. Mudholkar J. delivered a separate Judgment.

facts.text: Appellants convicted under s. 73 of the Indian Mines Act for contravention of Rule 7 of the Mines Creche Rules, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: interpretation of s. 18 of the Mines Act, 1952, which is in these words- Duties and responsibilities of owners, agents and managers- The owner, agent and manager of every mine shall be responsible that all operations carried on in connection therewith are conducted in accordance with the provisions of this Act and of the regulations, rules and bye-laws and of any orders made thereunder.

anchor.surface_text: The Mines Creche Rules are no less conditions of female labour than are the provisions of, say, s. 46 of the Act. That section prohibits the employment of women in a mine which is below ground and also employment of women in mines above ground except between 6 a.m. and 7 p.m. except to the extent there is variation of the hours of employment above ground by the Central Government in exercise of the powers given by that very section.

concepts.interpretation: Provisions on women employment analogous to creche rules as conditions of employment

issues.text: whether the Mines Creche Rules, 1946, had stood repealed, along with the repeal by s. 88 of the Mines Act of 1952, of the Mines Act, 1923, under which these rules were admittedly framed

anchor.surface_text: The main contentions raised on behalf of the appellants are, 1 that the Mines Creche Rules, 1946, had stood repealed, along with the repeal by s. 88 of the Mines Act of 1952, of the Mines Act, 1923,. under which these rules were admittedly framed and, 2 they having been framed under s. 30 bb of the Mines Act, 1923, cannot be deemed to be rules made under the Mines Act, 1952,

issues.text: whether they having been framed under s. 30 bb of the Mines Act, 1923, can be deemed to be rules made under the Mines Act, 1952, as the requirements of the corresponding section of the 1952 Act, viz., s. 58 d are different from what is required by s. 30 bb of the 1923 Act

anchor.surface_text: 2 they having been framed under s. 30 bb of the Mines Act, 1923, cannot be deemed to be rules made under the Mines Act, 1952, as. the requirements of the corresponding section of the 1952 Act, viz., s. 58 b are different from what is required by s. 30 bb of the 1923 Act. In Criminal Appeals Nos. 98 to 106 of 1959 we have decided that regulations framed under s. 29 of the Mines Act, 1923, survive the repeal of that Act. The same reasons which form the basis of that decision apply to the rules framed under s. 30 of the Mines Act, 1923 and so, the first contention raised on behalf of the appellants must be rejected as unsound. The second question arises in this way.

issues.text: whether the manager having no duty to perform under Rule 7 1 of the Creche Rules no question of his contravening the same by omission to appoint a creche-in-charge arises

anchor.surface_text: On an examination of the evidence adduced in the case before the Magistrate, we find that the Jawabad Mine was one, where women were ordinarily employed. With regard to this Mine therefore the Mines Creche Rules operated as rules under the 1952 Act and consequently, contravention of Rule 7 of the Mines Creche Rules, 1946, was in law a contravention of a rule made under the 1952 Act, within the meaning of s. 73 of that Act. On behalf of the second appellant, Gupta, who was the manager of the colliery at the relevant time, a further contention is raised. It is pointed out that Rule 7 1 does not in terms lay any duty on the manager and it is contended that the manager having no duty to perform under Rule 7 1 of the Creche Rules no question of his contravening the same by omission to appoint a creche-in-charge arises. The answer to this question depends on the interpretation of s. 18 of the Mines Act, 1952,

issues.text: whether the Mines Creche Rules have anything to do with operations carried on in connection with the mine and s. 18 deals only with the proper observance of the provisions of the Act directly touching the work carried on in the mines

anchor.surface_text: The first contention urged on behalf of the appellant is that the Mines Creche Rules have nothing to do with operations carried on in the mines and that s. 18 deals only with the proper observance of the provisions of the Act directly touching the work carried on in the mines, for raising coal and allied activities. In our opinion that will be an unduly narrow interpretation of the section. The employment of female labour is obviously and admittedly connected with the raising of coal in the mine and all conditions of employment of female labour should reasonably be held to be inextricably connected with operations carried on in the mines.

holdings.text: The Mines Creche Rules, 1946 framed under s.30 of the Mines Act, 1923 survive the repeal of that Act.

anchor.surface_text: In Criminal Appeals Nos. 98 to 106 of 1959 we have decided that regulations framed under s. 29 of the Mines Act, 1923, survive the repeal of that Act. The same reasons which form the basis of that decision apply to the rules framed under s. 30 of the Mines Act, 1923 and so,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows reasoning from court's recent decision in Criminal Appeals Nos. 98-106 of 1959 holding similar regulations under s.29 survive repeal.

holdings.text: Mines Creche Rules, 1946 continue in force by virtue of s.24 General Clauses Act to the extent provisions of s.58(d) Mines Act 1952 and s.30(bb) Mines Act 1923 overlap.

anchor.surface_text: To the extent the provisions of s. 58 d  of the 1950 Act and s. 30 bb  of the earlier enactment overlap, these rules would continue in force by virtue of s. 24 of the General Clauses Act. On an examination of the evidence adduced in the case before the Magistrate,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Overlapping rule-making powers allow continuation post-repeal under General Clauses Act s.24; rules cover part of s.58(d) scope.

holdings.text: Jawbad Mine was one where women were ordinarily employed, so contravention of Rule 7 of Mines Creche Rules 1946 is contravention of rule under Mines Act 1952 punishable under s.73.

anchor.surface_text: On an examination of the evidence adduced in the case before the Magistrate, we find that the Jawabad Mine was one, where women were ordinarily employed. With regard to this Mine therefore the Mines Creche Rules operated as rules under the 1952 Act and consequently,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court examines evidence and finds factual precondition met for rules' application under 1952 Act.

holdings.text: Mines Creche Rules relate to operations carried on in connection with the mine and fall within s.18 Mines Act 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The first contention urged on behalf of the appellant is that the Mines Creche Rules have nothing to do with operations carried on in the mines and that s. 18 deals only with the proper observance of the provisions of the Act directly touching the work carried on in the mines,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects narrow interpretation; creche rules are conditions of female labour inextricably connected with mining operations, analogous to s.46.

holdings.text: Owner, agent and manager are responsible under s.18(1) Mines Act 1952 for observance of Mines Creche Rules.

anchor.surface_text: Observance of these rules is therefore necessary before operations can be said to have been carried on in accordance with the rules made under the Act. In our opinion, therefore, the effect of s. 18 1  is that all three-the manager, the agent and the owner-are responsible

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.18(1) imposes general responsibility on all three for conducting operations per Act and rules, including creche rules as employment conditions.

holdings.text: Manager deemed guilty of contravention under s.18(2) unless proves took all reasonable means to prevent; Gupta failed to prove.

anchor.surface_text: The Mines Creche Rules are no less conditions of female labour than are the provisions of, say, s. 46 of the Act. That section prohibits the employment of women in a mine which is below ground and also employment of women in mines above ground except between 6 a.m. and 7 p.m.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.18(2) imposes vicarious liability on owner/agent/manager for any contravention by any person; defence available but not established here.

holdings.text: State v. Deodatta Diddi (Nagpur HC) not applicable as did not consider s.18 Mines Act.

anchor.surface_text: In support of his contention that the law does not impose any duty on the manager of the mines to carry out the provisions of the Creche Rules, Mr. Majumdar relied on a decision of the Nagpur High Court in the State Government, P. v Deodatta Diddi  1 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower court overlooked key statutory provision s.18.

holdings.text: In G.D. Bhattar (Calcutta HC), the view holding manager liable under s.18 for creche rules is correct.

anchor.surface_text: The question as regards the liability of any agent or manager of the mine for the construction of pithead baths or of mine creches appears to have been raised before the Calcutta High Court in G. D. Bhattar v. The State  1 . In that case both the learned Judges considered s. 18

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agrees with one judge's interpretation of s.18 over the other.

holdings.text: Manager not vicariously liable under s.18 for owner's failure to appoint creche in-charge under Rule 7(1) as s.18 concerns mining operations, not management/amenities; no power to enforce owner's duty.

anchor.surface_text: While I agree to the order proposed with respect to Mohan Lal Goenka, I am of the opinion that the conviction of the appellant Gupta who was a manager of the mines cannot be sustained. It has throughout been accepted that under r. 7 1  of the Mines Creche Rules, 1946,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dissent: s.18 in Chapter IV limited to mining operations; creches are management amenities; manager lacks power to enforce owner's duty; defence implies enforceability.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeals Nos. 98 to 106 of 1959 we have decided that regulations framed under s. 29 of the Mines Act, 1923, survive the repeal of that Act. The same reasons which form the basis of that decision apply to the rules f

precedents.citation: State Government, P. v Deodatta Diddi [...] A.I.R. 1956 Nag. 71

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Majumdar relied on a decision of the Nagpur High Court in the State Government, P. v Deodatta Diddi 1 . The question there was whether one Deodatta Diddi, Agent, Rawanwara Khas Colliery, could be held to have contravened rule 3(1) of the Coal Mines Pithead Bath Rules, 1946, where no pithead baths had been con- structed as required by the rules.

precedents.cited_proposition: the owner alone who could be deemed to have contravened the rule and that the Agent even assuming that he was the representative of the owner in respect of the management of the colliery had no duty to perform in this matter
precedents.cited_holding: Agent not liable for contravention of rule requiring owner to construct pithead baths

precedents.citation: G. D. Bhattar v. The State [...] A.I.R. 1957 Cal. 483

anchor.surface_text: The question as regards the liability of any agent or manager of the mine for the construction of pithead baths or of mine creches appears to have been raised before the Calcutta High Court in G. D. Bhattar v. The State 1 . In that case both the learned Judges considered s. 18 of the Mines Act, 1952, but came to different conclusions, one of them holding that under s. 18 the manager would be liable for carrying out the provisions of these rules while the other learned Judge took a different view.

precedents.case_name: G. D. Bhattar v. The State
precedents.cited_proposition: liability of manager under s. 18 of the Mines Act, 1952 for carrying out provisions of rules on creches/pithead baths
precedents.cited_holding: conflicting views: one holding manager liable, the other not

anchor.surface_text: The Mines Creche Rules are no less conditions of female labour than are the provisions of, say, s. 46 of the Act. That section prohibits the employment of women in a mine which is below ground and also employment of women in mines above ground except between 6 a.m. and 7 p.m.
The appeal is accordingly dismissed.
